abstracts.cdata!:
The project rating is satisfactory,
            sustainability is highly likely, and the institutional
            development impact is substantial. However, and in contrast
            to the satisfactory performance of the Borrower, the Bank
            performance is unsatisfactory, on the grounds that project
            design, with too many unrelated sub-components, led to
            unsustainable supervision costs, and, the process to
            restructure the project, and cancel credit lines, should
            have been taken much earlier. Lessons suggest that project
            design, and preparation be simple, to avoid multiple
            objectives requiring substantial supervision resources, and,
            long implementation periods impose high costs in terms of
            Government oversight, potentially reducing flexibility.
            Credit lines design should consider a banking environment
            with no distortions, or at least only few distortions, in
            the credit markets. Interest rate ceilings existed in Cyprus
            at the time the Bank extended the credit line, and it
            negatively affected credit demand. Furthermore, under
            intense restructuring of the enterprise sector, private
            financing needs become difficult to assess, thus it would be
            preferable to initiate smaller credit lines to be tested,
            and perfected in time, to form a solid base in assessing the
            real demand. Technical assistance should be clearly defined,
            not financed by the Bank if grant funds are available, and,
            should be responsive to client needs.

5082099.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Environment and natural resource management,Trade and integration

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's principal objective
            is to assist the Government in undertaking a substantial
            adjustment of its industrial sector in view of a gradual
            integration with the European Community (EC).  The project
            consists of: (a) support for setting up a framework of
            policies and programs for restructuring the industrial
            sector, including dispositions concerning environmental
            considerations; (b) the introduction of a strengthened
            regulatory and supervisory framework for increasing the
            soundness and efficiency of financial institutions,
            particularly as regards the cooperative banking network; (c)
            a program for increasing the financial autonomy of the
            Cyprus Development Bank (CDB); and (d) a credit facility to
            support the investment and working capital needs of eligible
            industrial enterprises undertaking restructuring programs.
            The project also provides for technical assistance in five
            areas: (a) assistance in undertaking competitive enhancement
            and environmental impact studies for specific enterprises;
            (b) assistance in developing quality control mechanisms for
            manufactured products; (c) development of project appraisal
            capabilities within participating banks (PBs); (d) the
            preparation of an action program for developing capital
            markets; and (e) development of the local industrial and
            environmental consulting capacity along with strengthening
            of the environmental auditing and control mechanisms.
